user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static int irq_notify_fd
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
...
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I analyzed the provided fragments for code that can never be executed (unreachable code). No such unreachable code patterns were found in the supplied snippets: 

- metal_linux_irq_notify: all statements are reachable. The write call can succeed or fail; the conditional block (if (ret < 0)) is executed only on error but is not unreachable, and the final return is the normal exit. There is no code after a return or any unconditional jump that makes subsequent code unreachable.

- metal_log macro: expands to a statement-expression that conditionally calls the log handler. The conditional call is reachable depending on the runtime values of _metal.common.log_handler and _metal.common.log_level; this is not unreachable code.

- metal_linux_irq_set_enable: the early return on invalid irq is reachable when the function is called with an out-of-range irq; the remainder of the function is reachable for valid irq values. No statements are dead/unreachable.

- metal_linux_irq_shutdown: execution flow (set flag, notify, join thread, close fd, deinit mutex) is linear and reachable; no unreachable statements are present.

I did not detect any code that is syntactically or semantically impossible to reach in the provided fragments. If there are other parts of the project (not shown) that use constructs such as #if 0, macros that expand to unconditional returns, unconditional infinite loops with no escape, or code present after an unconditional return within the same block, those would need to be reported as suspicious; however, such constructs are not present in the supplied code snippets.
